sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Atila Fassina)
articles.description: Are you ready for a little exercise of pulling a framework apart and putting the pieces back together? In this article, Atila Fassina explains how meta-frameworks have evolved around core libraries in their own unique ways.
articles.title: SolidStart: A Different Breed Of Meta-Framework

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: The View Transitions API is a new — but game-changing — feature that allows us to do the types of reactive state-based UI and page transitions that have traditionally been exclusive to JavaScript frameworks. In the second half of this mini two-part series, Adrian Bece expands on the demos from the first article to demonstrate how the View Transitions API can be used to transition not just elements between two states but the transition between full views and pages in single-page and multi-page applications.
articles.title: The View Transitions API And Delightful UI Animations (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s start into the new year with a little inspiration boost: wallpapers created with love by the community for the community. Happy 2024!
articles.title: The Magic Of New Beginnings (January 2024 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Juan Diego Rodríguez)
articles.description: JavaScript may be the most popular client-side language in the world, but it’s far from perfect and not without its quirks. Juan Diego Rodriguez examines several “absurd” JavaScript eccentricities and explains how they made it into the language as well as how to avoid them in your own code.
articles.title: Making Sense Of “Senseless” JavaScript Features

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: The View Transitions API is a new — but game-changing — feature that allows us to do the types of reactive state-based UI and page transitions that have traditionally been exclusive to JavaScript frameworks. In the first part of this mini two-part series, Adrian Bece thoroughly explains why we need the API and demonstrates its basic usage.
articles.title: The View Transitions API And Delightful UI Animations (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Šime Vidas)
articles.description: Since the introduction of CSS viewport units in 2012, many of us have been using `width: 100vw` as a way to set an element’s width to the full width of the viewport. But, as Šime Vidas explains in this deep dive, `100vw` does not always represent the full width of the viewport due to differences in how browsers handle scrollbars.
articles.title: New CSS Viewport Units Do Not Solve The Classic Scrollbar Problem

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Luis Ouriach)
articles.description: Part 2 concentrates on the key points from Luis’ framework and practical tips about managing a design system that should be both robust and easy to adopt.
articles.title: Building Components For Consumption, Not Complexity (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Brecht De Ruyte)
articles.description: Have you run into a situation where you need the padding of one element to align with the padding of another element? In this article, Brecht De Ruyte demonstrates the issue with a full-width slider component that breaks out of the main page container and shares a couple of techniques to keep it visually aligned with other elements on the page.
articles.title: CSS Scroll Snapping Aligned With Global Page Layout: A Full-Width Slider Case Study

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Luis Ouriach)
articles.description: Design systems can be of immense help, but failure to adopt them invalidates the hard work that goes into building the thing in the first place! In this two-part series of articles, Luis shares his experience with design systems and how you can overcome the potential pitfalls.
articles.title: Building Components For Consumption, Not Complexity (Part 1)

articles.author: Daniel Kehoe
articles.description: Beginners often get confused when configuring Zsh shell on a Mac. Zsh shell offers four configuration files with no discernible differences. Particularly, ~/.zshrc and ~/.zprofile appear to be identical, leaving us wondering which one to use.  In this article, you'll learn the difference and a simple guideline for your
articles.title: How Do Zsh Configuration Files Work?

articles.author: Joan Ayebola
articles.description: RESTful APIs are a crucial component in modern web development. They allow communication between different applications over the internet.  REST (which stands for Representational State Transfer) APIs operate on a stateless client-server architecture, providing a standardized way to create, read, update, and delete resources. Integrating RESTful APIs with React
articles.title: How Work with RESTful APIs in React

articles.author: Reed Barger
articles.description: In this guide, I'll break down a complete roadmap that will cover all the concepts, libraries, and tools to help you become a React developer in 2024. My goal is to show you the happy path in React, navigating you away from pitfalls so you can spend your time on
articles.title: The React Roadmap for 2024 – How to Learn React

articles.author: TAPAS ADHIKARY
articles.description: Developers love productivity. When it comes to coding, we want to do things fast and we look out for opportunities to re-use things as much as possible. Say, you are getting started with a ReactJS project and want to use TailwindCSS  for the same. The first time, it would
articles.title: How to Build a GitHub Template Repository for Scaffolding with React, Vite, and TailwindCSS

articles.author: Andrico Karoulla
articles.description: For the last 7 months, I’ve had my head down building Component Odyssey [https://component-odyssey.com/]. It’s been a richly fulfilling project and I’m eager for people to take the course and learn heaps about building component libraries using web components. I’ve seen some incredible demos over the past year, and wanted
articles.title: How to Use New CSS Features to Build a Progress Indicator

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: The world of data analysis is vast and continually evolving, and staying ahead in this field requires a solid foundation in its core technologies and methodologies. We just published a 19-hour data analysis bootcamp on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel. This bootcamp, developed by Alex Freberg, provides an immersive learning experience
articles.title: Learn Data Analysis with Comprehensive 19-Hour Bootcamp

articles.author: Ashutosh Biswas
articles.description: pnpm is like npm, but it's way faster and more efficient. After all, the starting p stands for performant. According to its creator, Zoltan Kochan, pnpm "allows you to save gigabytes of disk space." Many popular projects including Next.js, Vite, Svelte, and even freeCodeCamp use pnpm. So now is a
articles.title: How to Use pnpm – Installation and Common Commands

articles.author: Okosa Leonard Onyekachukwu
articles.description: When developing your web applications, you should always consider search engine optimization (SEO) techniques. Many things come into play when you're making sure your web application operates as intended and has an online presence. Search engines such as Google, Bing, and Yahoo serve as the primary medium for users seeking
articles.title: How to Make React Apps SEO-Friendly – A Handbook for Beginners

articles.author: Faith Oyama
articles.description: Serverless architecture has become a hot topic in the developer world, and for good reason.  It promises a paradigm shift – one where we leave behind the burdens of server management and focus solely on building and deploying code. No more provisioning VMs, patching software, or scaling infrastructure manually.
articles.title: Serverless Architecture Patterns and Best Practices

articles.author: Zubair Idris Aweda
articles.description: JavaScript arrays are one of the most important data structures in the language, since everything is already an object in JavaScript. They're useful in so many applications, and many other data structures build on top of JavaScript arrays and objects. While the language provides a lot of helpful array and
articles.title: Collect.js Tutorial – How to Work with JavaScript Arrays and Objects
